message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Toxoplasma gondii infection in neonates can cause hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis, and intracranial calcifications. The other options are associated with congenital syphilis, which is not caused by T. gondii.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. T. gondii infection in neonates can cause hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis, and intracranial calcifications. Option A is associated with congenital rubella, while option B is associated with congenital syphilis. Option C is not specifically associated with any congenital infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Congenital toxoplasmosis can cause a range of symptoms, but the most common ones are hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis, and intracranial calcifications, which are associated with option D. The other options are associated with congenital syphilis (B), congenital rubella syndrome (C), and patent ductus arteriosus is not a common manifestation of any congenital infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. T. gondii infection in neonates is associated with hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis, and intracranial calcifications. Option A describes findings associated with congenital rubella syndrome. Option B describes findings associated with congenital syphilis. Option C describes findings associated with congenital cytomegalovirus infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. T. gondii infection in neonates is associated with hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis, and intracranial calcifications. Patent ductus arteriosus, cataracts, deafness, Hutchinson’s teeth, saddle nose, and short maxilla are all associated with congenital syphilis. Deafness, seizures, and petechial rash are associated with congenital rubella syndrome.

Option A is associated with congenital rubella, option B is associated with congenital syphilis, and option C is associated with congenital CMV.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. T. gondii infection in neonates is associated with hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis, and intracranial calcifications. The other options are associated with congenital syphilis (B), congenital rubella (C), and congenital cytomegalovirus (A).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. T. gondii infection can cause congenital toxoplasmosis in neonates, which can present with symptoms such as hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis, and intracranial calcifications. The other options describe symptoms associated with congenital syphilis (B), congenital rubella syndrome (A), and meningitis (C), respectively.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. T. gondii infection in neonates is associated with hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis, and intracranial calcifications. Options A, B, and C are associated with other congenital infections such as rubella, syphilis, and CMV.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. T. gondii infection in neonates is associated with hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis, and intracranial calcifications. Patent ductus arteriosus, cataracts, deafness belong to Congenital Rubella Syndrome. Hutchinson’s teeth, saddle nose, short maxilla belong to Congenital Syphilis. Deafness, seizures, petechial rash belong to Congenital CMV Infection.
